title: Kelward
author: Kelward
content: I don reason di possibility of how we fit to de take bitcoin de make payments, just like naira, inside Nigeria. E come lead me to wonder weda na di private or public sector go fit to make am possible pass, at di end I come conclude say na di public sector, way be government establishments go fit to facilitate di acceptance of bitcoin pass. Dis na primarily because di private sector no get di kind centralized authority wey di public sector get, government fit wake up one day and decide say dem wan de collect bitcoin as an alternative to naira inside dem establshments. You go see say overnight bitcoin don get popularity be dat and di adoption go accelerate.  Aldo as e be now I no see di possibility of di government say dem go adopt cryptocurrency, na through our banks dem go de facilitate di transactions. As we know di CBN restrictions on crypto matter still de ground, so dat one na very big set back. Lagos state government, don commission train to de run from Marina to mile 2, dem also put di transport fares, assuming say dem add bitcoin as an alternative means of payment, dat one for blow bitcoin usage for Lagos state. BRT buses get card wey passengers de load transport payments, if you wan enter di bus you go just hold di card in front of di card metre and your transport fate go deduct. So dis system for just suit bitcoin holders wey wan purchase transport fare. Dem no go worry about making bitcoin transfer for bus stop. Imaging if power distribution companies, NPA, public schools, government higher institutions, general hospitals and all government revenue generation agencies come approve bitcoin, di private sector go just respectfully, without much choice, follow de collect am.So wetin you reason about di matter?

comments.body: The public sector is probably the best sector when it comes mass adoption of anything not just Bitcoin, and I de sure for Bitcoin aspect, e go they easier as well but challenges go de.Me and you know the kind government wey we get, and anything wey go make them no see money chop dem no de accept am, and you know say Bitcoin transaction can be tracked in the blockchain which will be transparent for everyone to see the amount of Bitcoin been sent to the government wallet address, and the government will not be that free to chop dat money because eye de d money, as a result that, dem no go gree.

The exchanges we have are all P2P and this is individual adoption from people who buy and sell bitcoin.

comments.author: Promocodeudo
comments.body: Op you made a good point here, the government has made this impossible, Our government is bent on killing ideas, is not as if they don't know all this, but they prefer controlling all the monetary aspects, they don't want any other means, but I must tell you some of our government officials are into crypto and they understand bitcoin more than we do, but they can opt for it, because they see it as a danger, remember bitcoin is decentralized, meaning that it can not be censored or controlled by any entity or institution, just imagine when you can perform all your transactions both purchasing of things online, payment of electricity bills, airline tickets, etc, that's to say that the cash itself will be useless, your idea is in the right track but the people in the helm of affairs, will not buy this idea because of their selfish motives, our government want a total control of their citizens, so this won't be a good option for them.

I know say once once them go dey talk dey mention Bitcoin and Blockchain technology, but since them dey speak grammar you don see them do anything wey show say them ready reason the adoption? E go shock you say if one big country make Bitcoin a legal tender, come dey use am well for their country, Naija go copy. If we want make Bitcoin go far for Nigeria, na the private sector go drive am. Normally, Naija love news and things wey dey trend. The moment plenty privately owned businesses start to dey accept Bitcoin, I mean big name them, you go see our government go begin shake body go that side.
